title: 113_hr984
content: The Task Force on Urotrauma is discussed in Section 1. The Secretary of Defense will establish the Task Force on Urotrauma to study urotrauma among Armed Forces members and veterans, including analyzing incidence, morbidity, mortality rates, social, and economic costs. The Task Force on Urotrauma will evaluate facilities, resources, and research related to diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of urotrauma. It will also assess programs improving prevention or treatment, develop a long-term plan for resource utilization, analyze shortfalls in research for female victims, and explore mechanisms for enhanced reproductive services. The Task Force on Urotrauma will assess opportunities to enhance coordination of federal resources for research and care, as well as provide updates to the report. Membership includes 16 members appointed by the Secretary of Defense. The Task Force on Urotrauma consists of 16 members appointed by the Secretary of Defense, one member appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Chief of the Department of Surgery of Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, and the Chief Medical Director of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Additionally, there are nonvoting, ex officio members including the Surgeon Generals of the Navy, Army, and Air Force. The Task Force on Urotrauma is comprised of members appointed by the Secretary of Defense, Secretary of Health and Human Services, and other medical professionals. The qualifications for appointing members include experience in studying or researching urotrauma, and preventing or treating urotrauma. The Task Force on Urotrauma members serve for life, vacancies are filled as per original appointment, and members receive travel expenses. The Task Force on Urotrauma members receive per diem, constitute a quorum with a majority, and the Secretary of Defense designates a chairperson. The Task Force has a director appointed by the chairperson and additional staff can be appointed as needed. Certain civil service laws apply to the Task Force. The Task Force director and staff are appointed under civil service laws, paid according to specific provisions, and may procure temporary services. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Task Force upon request. The Task Force may hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and receive evidence as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Task Force, and official data can be obtained from US departments or agencies. The Task Force can request information from government departments, use the United States mails, and receive administrative support services. They are also required to submit interim reports to Congress within one year of appointment. The Task Force must submit an interim report to Congress within one year of appointment and a final report with recommendations on urotrauma prevention and treatment for Armed Forces and veterans within two years. The Task Force will terminate 60 days after submitting the final report. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "urotrauma" is defined as injury to the urinary tract from various causes. Authorization of appropriations is set at $1,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2014 to 2017 for this section. The appropriation for operation and maintenance, Defense-wide, for the Office of the Secretary of Defense for fiscal years 2014 through 2017 is reduced by $1,000,000.
